title: Research
text:
The impact of covid-19 on real estate markets in Germany

with Lukas Hörnig, and Patrick Thiel

Housing supply elasticity in Germany [draft]

Abstract
This study provides housing supply elasticity estimates for Germany in the years 2008-2019, using Bartik shocks as housing demand shifter. Housing supply turns out to be quite inelastic in the average district, 0.25 for floorspace and 0.19 for units. Variation in existing levels of development intensity, measured by the fraction of land that is already developed, and in land unavailability due to area covered by wetlands, water bodies and steep slopes, partially explains the heterogeneity of housing supply elasticities across districts. Both of these supply constraints significantly lower housing supply elasticity.

title: Welcome to my Blog
text: I will blog about what I have learned in my Rand Python journey. Stay tuned!

title: Welcome
text: My name is Eyayaw Beze, and I am a PhD candidate at the University of Duisburg-Essen. My research areas are urban and regional economics, with a particular focus on housing markets issues. Besides, I am highly interested in data science with R and Python.

title: Bio
text:
Shumshuha -- Lalibela Airport


I went to Bahir Dar University for my undergrad, for master’s to KDI School in South Korea, and to Budapest, Regensburg, and Trento for a joint European master in comparative local development (Master CoDe).
For more than three years, I worked for Jimma University, department of Economics, where I taught undergrad economics courses.
Now, I am a PhD candidate at the University of Duisburg-Essen.
